information: Chris Stapleton received six nominations for the 60th Academy of Country Music Awards. His nominations are for Male Artist of the Year, Entertainer of the Year, Album of the Year, Single of the Year, Music Event of the Year (with Carly Pearce), and Visual Media of the Year. Other top nominees include Ella Langley with eight nominations, and Cody Johnson and Morgan Wallen, who are tied with seven nominations each. Lainey Wilson also received six nominations.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: Yes — given multiple nominations and Stapleton’s track record, he’s likely to win at least one award.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: He’s shut out across all categories due to strong competition (e.g., Morgan Wallen, Cody Johnson, Lainey Wilson) and vote-splitting; collaborative/visual categories go to other high-profile pairings or viral videos.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: He wins Male Artist of the Year or one of the collaboration/media categories (e.g., Music Event with Carly Pearce), or takes Album/Single of the Year in a close race.
forecast.rationale: Time is short to the event, so current nomination slate and industry sentiment dominate. Stapleton reportedly has six nominations spanning major (Male Artist, Entertainer, Album, Single) and collaboration/media (Music Event, Visual Media) categories. Breadth across categories lowers the chance of a total shutout compared to having all eggs in one basket. Historically, multi-nominated, established artists like Stapleton often secure at least one ACM win, and he is a perennial winner with strong critical and commercial credentials. Competition is stiff this cycle: Ella Langley leads nominations (8), Cody Johnson and Morgan Wallen have 7 each, and Lainey Wilson is a recent juggernaut. That reduces his odds in top-line categories like Entertainer and increases the possibility of vote-splitting in Single/Album. Nonetheless, Music Event and Visual Media offer additional viable paths. Why not higher? Entertainer is a long shot; Single/Album face blockbuster rivals; ACMs sometimes spread awards across multiple artists, creating plausible paths to a shutout. Why not lower? Six nominations across diverse categories and Stapleton’s reputation make at least one win more likely than not. I’d update up if credible industry previews or expert ballots strongly favor him in Male Artist or confirm frontrunner status in Music Event/Visual Media; down if pre-show chatter and expert picks coalesce around rivals in all of his categories or if his nomination count is fewer than reported.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will Chris Stapleton win an award at the 60th Academy of Country Music Awards?

Question background:
The awards are scheduled to be held on May 8, 2025. Stapleton has 5 nominations.


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if Chris Stapleton wins an award at the [60th Academy of Country Music Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/60th_Academy_of_Country_Music_Awards).




Your research assistant's report says:
Chris Stapleton received six nominations for the 60th Academy of Country Music Awards. His nominations are for Male Artist of the Year, Entertainer of the Year, Album of the Year, Single of the Year, Music Event of the Year (with Carly Pearce), and Visual Media of the Year. Other top nominees include Ella Langley with eight nominations, and Cody Johnson and Morgan Wallen, who are tied with seven nominations each. Lainey Wilson also received six nominations.

Today is 2025-04-22.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
